segments.speaker: IELTS_Examiner
segments.text: Test 2. This is the IELTS listening test. You will hear a number of different recordings and you will have to answer questions on what you hear. There will be time for you to read the instructions and questions and you will have a chance to check your work. All the recordings will be played once only. The test is in four parts. At the end of the test you will be given 10 minutes to transfer your answers to an answer sheet. Now turn to part one. Part one. You will hear a woman from a job agency giving information to a man about work in a chain of restaurants. First, you have some time to look at questions one to five. Now listen carefully and answer questions 1 to 5.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: So I understand you're interested in restaurant work? Yes.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: I've got a bit of experience and I can provide references. That's

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: good. I can check all that later. Now, Milo's restaurants have some vacancies at the moment. They're a really good company to work for. Lots of benefits. Alright. Yes. They've got a very good reputation for looking after staff. For example, all employees get training, even temporary staff.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: Oh, really? That's quite unusual, isn't it? Certainly is. And do staff get free uniforms too?

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: Erm, you just need to wear a white T-shirt and black trousers, it says here. So, I guess not. But another benefit of working for a big company like this is that you can get a discount at any of their restaurants.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: Even at weekends?

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: No, but you'll be working then anyway.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: Oh yes, I suppose so. Most of their restaurants are in the city centre, aren't they? So easy to get to by bus?

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: Yes, that's right. But if you have to do a late shift and finish work after midnight, the company will pay for you to get a taxi home.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: I probably won't need one. I think I'd use my bike. OK.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: Now, they do have some quite specific requirements for the kind of person they're looking for. Milo's is a young dynamic company and they're really keen on creating a strong team. It's really important that you can fit in and get on well with everyone.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: Yeah, I've got no problem with that. It sounds good actually. The last place I worked for was quite demanding too. We had to make sure we gave a really high level of service.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: That's good to hear because that will be equally important at Milo's. I know they want people who have an eye for detail.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: That's fine. I'm very used to working in that kind of environment.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: Perfect. So the only other thing that's required is good communication skills, so you'll need to have a certificate in English. Sure.

segments.speaker: IELTS_Examiner
segments.text: Before you hear the rest of the conversation, you have some time to look at questions 6 to 10. Now listen and answer questions 6 to 10.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: OK, let's have a look at the current job vacancies at Milo's. The first one is in Wivenhoe Street. Sorry, where? Wivenhoe. W-I-V-E-N-H-O-E. It's quite central, just off Cork Street. Oh, right. They're looking for a breakfast supervisor. That would be OK. So you're probably familiar with the kind of responsibilities involved. Obviously checking that all the portions are correct, etc. And then things like checking all the procedures for cleaning the equipment

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: are being followed. OK. And what about the salary? In my last job I was getting £9.50 per hour. I was hoping to get a bit more than that.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: Well, to begin with you'd be getting £9.75, but that goes up to £11.25 after three months.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: That's not too bad. And I suppose it's a very early start.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: That's the only unattractive thing about this job. But then you have the afternoons and evenings free, so the restaurant starts serving breakfast from 7am and you'd have to be there at 5.30 to set everything up, but you'd be finished at 12.30. Hmm.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: Well, as you say, there are advantages to that.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: Now, you might also be interested in the job at the City Road branch. That's for a junior chef, so again, a position of responsibility. I might prefer that, actually. Right. Well, obviously this role would involve supporting the sous chef and other senior staff, and you'd be responsible for making sure there's enough stock each week and sorting out all the deliveries.

segments.speaker: Job_Seeker
segments.text: I've never done that before, but I imagine it's fairly straightforward once you get the hang of it.

segments.speaker: Job_Agent
segments.text: Yes, and you'd be working alongside more experienced staff to begin with, so I'm sure it wouldn't be a problem. The salary's slightly higher here. It's an annual salary of £23,000. Right. I know that if they like you, it's likely you'll be promoted quite quickly, so that's worth thinking about. Yes, it does sound interesting. What are the hours like? The usual, I think. There's a lot of evening and weekend work, but they're closed on Mondays. But you do get one Sunday off every four weeks. So, would you like me to send off your CV?

segments.speaker: IELTS_Examiner
segments.text: That is the end of part one. You now have one minute to check your answers to part one.
